questions.title: The Bridge Riddle
questions.question: Four people need to cross a bridge at night with only one torch. The bridge can hold only two people at a time. Person A takes 1 minute, B takes 2 minutes, C takes 5 minutes, and D takes 10 minutes. What's the minimum time needed for all to cross?

options.text: 17 minutes

effect.feedback: Brilliant! A&B cross (2min), A returns (1min), C&D cross (10min), B returns (2min), A&B cross (2min) = 17 minutes total!

options.text: 18 minutes

effect.feedback: Close! Try optimizing who crosses together.

options.text: 19 minutes

effect.feedback: There's a more efficient strategy.

options.text: 21 minutes

effect.feedback: That's the simple approach. Think strategically!

hints: The slowest should cross together
Think about who should return with the torch

questions.title: The Water Jug Problem
questions.question: You have a 5-liter jug and a 3-liter jug. How can you measure exactly 4 liters of water?

options.text: Fill 5L, pour into 3L (leaving 2L), empty 3L, pour the 2L into 3L, fill 5L again, pour into 3L until full (adds 1L), leaving 4L in 5L jug

effect.feedback: Excellent problem-solving! You earned a sash fragment!

options.text: Fill 3L twice and estimate

effect.feedback: That's not precise. Think step-by-step.

options.text: Use both jugs alternately until it looks right

effect.feedback: You need an exact measurement strategy.

options.text: It's impossible with these jugs

effect.feedback: Don't give up! There's always a solution.

hints: Work backwards from 4 liters
Use the difference between jug sizes

questions.question: Connect all 9 dots arranged in a 3x3 grid using only 4 straight lines without lifting your pen. What's the key insight?

options.text: Think outside the box - extend lines beyond the grid boundary

effect.feedback: Perfect! Creative thinking means breaking assumptions!

options.text: Use diagonal lines only within the grid

effect.feedback: That won't connect all dots in 4 lines.

options.text: It's impossible with 4 lines

effect.feedback: Challenge your assumptions!

options.text: Use very thick lines to cover multiple dots

questions.title: The Liar's Paradox
questions.question: Three guardians stand before you. One always tells the truth, one always lies, and one answers randomly. You can ask one yes/no question to one guardian to find the safe path. What do you ask?

options.text: Ask any guardian: 'If I asked you if the left path is safe, would you say yes?' - then go opposite if liar detected

effect.feedback: That could work with two guardians, but the random one complicates it.

options.text: Ask: 'If I asked the truth-teller which path is safe, what would they say?' to the middle guardian

effect.feedback: You don't know which one is which yet!

options.text: Ask any guardian: 'Is the left path safe?' and use probability

effect.feedback: Too risky with the random guardian!

options.text: Ask: 'If I asked you if you're the random guardian, would you say yes?' - the random one gives random answers

effect.feedback: Ingenious! Truth-teller says no, liar says no, random is random. You identified the pattern!

hints: The key is identifying the random guardian first
Both truth-teller and liar would answer consistently to meta-questions

questions.title: The Resource Dilemma
questions.scenario: As a temporary leader, you have limited resources. Two groups need help: one is larger but the situation is less critical; the other is smaller but in dire need.
questions.question: How do you allocate resources?

options.text: Prioritize the critical situation first, then help others with remaining resources

effect.feedback: Wise prioritization! You balance urgency with fairness.

options.text: Split resources equally regardless of urgency

effect.feedback: Fair, but not optimal. Sometimes equal isn't equitable.

options.text: Help the larger group to maximize impact

effect.feedback: Utilitarian, but you neglected urgent need.

options.text: Wait for more information before deciding

effect.feedback: Caution is good, but delayed action can be costly.

questions.title: The Monty Hall Problem
questions.question: You're on a game show with 3 doors. Behind one is a prize, behind the others nothing. You pick door 1. The host (who knows what's behind each door) opens door 3, revealing nothing. Should you switch to door 2?

options.text: Yes, switch! Probability increases to 2/3 if you switch

effect.feedback: Statistically brilliant! Switching gives you 2/3 chance vs 1/3 if you stay.

options.text: No, stay. It's now 50/50 between two doors

effect.feedback: Common misconception! The initial probabilities don't reset.

options.text: It doesn't matter, both choices are equal

effect.feedback: Actually, switching doubles your odds!

options.text: Flip a coin to decide

effect.feedback: Why leave it to chance when math can guide you?

hints: Consider the initial probability of your first choice
The host's knowledge changes the game

questions.title: The Cube Conundrum
questions.question: A cube is painted red on all six faces, then cut into 27 smaller equal cubes. How many small cubes have exactly two red faces?

effect.feedback: Excellent spatial reasoning! Edge cubes (excluding corners) = 12.
That's the number of corner cubes (with 3 faces).
That's the number of face centers (with 1 face).
You're counting too many. Focus on edge positions only.

hints: Visualize a 3x3x3 cube
Two-faced cubes are on edges but not corners

questions.title: The Island of Truth
questions.question: On an island, knights always tell the truth and knaves always lie. You meet two people. A says 'We are both knaves.' What are they?

options.text: A is a knave, B is a knight

effect.feedback: Perfect logic! A's statement is false (since a knight can't claim to be a knave), making A a knave and B a knight.

options.text: Both are knights

effect.feedback: If both were knights, A's statement would be false, creating a contradiction.

options.text: Both are knaves

effect.feedback: If A were a knave telling the truth about being a knave... contradiction!

options.text: A is a knight, B is a knave

effect.feedback: A knight would never claim to be a knave.

hints: What would a knight say about themselves?
Work backwards from A's statement

questions.title: The Egg Drop
questions.question: You have 2 eggs and a 100-floor building. You need to find the highest floor from which an egg can drop without breaking, using the fewest drops. What's the optimal strategy's maximum drops needed?

options.text: 14 drops

effect.feedback: Brilliant! Start at floor 14, then 27, 39, 50, etc. Worst case: 14 drops. Perfect strategy!

options.text: 50 drops

effect.feedback: That's binary search, but you only have 2 eggs!

options.text: 10 drops

effect.feedback: Close! But with 10 drops you can only guarantee up to 55 floors (10+9+8+...+1).

options.text: 100 drops

effect.feedback: Way too many! There's a much more efficient strategy.

hints: Use decreasing intervals
First egg establishes range, second egg finds exact floor

questions.title: The Prisoner's Dilemma
questions.question: Two prisoners can cooperate (stay silent) or defect (betray). If both cooperate: 1 year each. One defects: 0 years for defector, 3 for other. Both defect: 2 years each. What's the Nash equilibrium?

options.text: Both defect (even though both cooperating is better overall)

effect.feedback: Correct! Rational self-interest leads to suboptimal outcomes - a key insight in game theory.

options.text: Both cooperate for mutual benefit

effect.feedback: That's the optimal outcome, but not the Nash equilibrium. Without trust, defection is rational.

options.text: One cooperates, one defects

effect.feedback: This isn't stable - the cooperator would switch to defecting.

options.text: Random choice each time

effect.feedback: There's a stable strategy based on rational self-interest.

hints: Think about what's rational for each prisoner individually
Nash equilibrium is when no one can improve by changing strategy alone

questions.title: The Dunning-Kruger Question

options.text: People with low ability overestimate their competence, while experts underestimate theirs

effect.feedback: Exactly! Self-awareness of ignorance is a sign of wisdom.

options.text: Experts always know more than novices

effect.feedback: True, but that's not the Dunning-Kruger effect specifically.

options.text: Confidence and competence are always correlated

effect.feedback: Actually, the effect shows they're often inversely related!

options.text: Learning gets easier over time

effect.feedback: That's not what this cognitive bias describes.

hints: Think about confidence vs. competence
